Fields.DialogueText: *KNOCK*
Steregushchy! You've been sitting in that observatory pod of yours for the last few days. Please open up!
*CREEEAK*
Zdravstvuyte, Kapitan.
You look terrible! I know you blame yourself for that bomber slipping through our defenses and Midshipman Antonova getting hurt, but she's going to be okay. Have you been eating and getting sleep?
It was my fault, Kapitan. Our surveillance capabilities are inadequate. I have been busy researching possible improvements in these scientific journals...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you should take a little break - you need to look out for yourself too.
You're always up to date on the latest technology! Anything promising?
Your capabilities have been inadequate lately, haven't they?

Fields.DialogueText: As long as I have my coffee, there is no need to rest, Kapitan!
There has been so much scientific progress lately, it is difficult to say what is the most promising, Kapitan!
I have already admitted that, Kapitan. You do not have to remind me...
This latest journal describes the use of electromagnetic waves to detect objects. In fact, many countries have been investigating radio location technology.
Yes, I've heard rumors of that! Imagine a device that can detect enemies approaching in the dark or when visibility is poor during bad weather. It sounds like magic!
It is science, not magic, Kapitan.
Ha! Well, you don't have to take everything I say literally, Steregushchy.
So after the last battle, when you told me, "I care about you more than all the stars and planets in the sky! I'll always be here to protect you..." Did you really mean that?
Um, well... yes, I suppose! It seemed like an appropriate thing to say at the time...
Oh... I see. Your words sound a lot less convincing now than they did then, Kapitan...
*ALARM*
We've got Morganas ahead, Steregushchy!
Da, Kapitan...
@BATTLE
Oh, Steregushchy! I wasn't expecting to see you in the mess hall. I thought you were still researching in your observatory pod...
Well, you had advised me to take a break, Kapitan. I thought I should follow your advice...
Yes, that's great! Please, sit down with Midshipman Antonova and me and relax for a while!
I see that you and Midshipman Antonova are already halfway through your meal. I would hate to interrupt...
Comrade Steregushchy! I am happy to finally see you! I just got medical approval to get out of bed. It is nice to be able to walk around again, even if the bandages make movement a little difficult!
Apologies for not checking on you earlier - the Kapitan failed to mention you were conscious again. I was researching ways to improve our surveillance to keep you safer in the future.
Oh, do not worry about me, Steregushchy! I am feeling much better! The Kapitan was just telling a funny story and making me laugh so hard! It hurts my ribs, but it is good to smile again!
Yes, I see that you and the Kapitan are having quite a pleasant time together...

Fields.MenuText: Steregushchy, why are you acting so odd lately?
I regularly have meals with my junior officers. I need to keep my finger on the pulse of things!
It's hard not to have a pleasant time around Midshipman Antonova!

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... I suppose. She is certainly always in a sunny mood around you, Kapitan.
What do you mean, Kapitan? I am behaving as usual. You on the other hand...
Ha! I am sure that is not all you have your finger on, Kapitan!
Steregushchy, I think you've had too much coffee and not enough sleep. Why don't you get a cup of warm milk from the cook and go back to your observatory pod for a few hours of shuteye?
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! You should go and get some rest. You have been working too hard as usual!
So you are trying to get rid of me? I suppose you two would like some more time alone?
What do you mean, Comrade Steregushchy? Why would we need time alone?
*BOOM*
Morganas! Let's take care of them - but promise me you'll get some rest after this battle, Steregushchy!
I am not the one to make promises I cannot keep, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Steregushchy! I wasn't expecting you to come visit me in my quarters! I thought you were still busy in your observatory pod.
I needed another break from my research on radio location, Kapitan.
It's good that you're taking more time for breaks these days. It helps clear your mind - and makes you more efficient in the long run.
Da, Kapitan...
What's the matter? You've been acting very strangely since that incident with the bomber attack and Midshipman Antonova. Please don't feel like that was your fault.
Enough about my inadequacies! Why were you eating together with Midshipman Antonova in the mess the other day, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: We eat together all the time, Steregushchy. It's a small ship.
She was giving me an after action report. She'd just finished debriefing some sailors about the last battle.
We just happened to sit down at the same table at the same time - pure coincidence!

Fields.DialogueText: I wonder what else you do together with Midshipman Antonova on this small ship of ours, Kapitan!
I had heard rumors she does a lot of debriefing with sailors, Kapitan. I suppose what I heard is true.
People do not act randomly, Kapitan.
Steregushchy, I really don't know what to say. Midshipman Antonova and I have a strictly professional relationship. I think you're seeing something that I'm not.
I am seeing someone who told me "I care about you more than all the stars and planets in the sky! I'll always be here to protect you" spending their time chatting with Midshipman Antonova instead.
That is what I am seeing, Kapitan.
You shouldn't take these things so seriously, Steregushchy! Trust me - I meant what I told you.
Based on my observations, I am finding that difficult to believe, Kapitan.
*BOOM*
Morganas again! I have to get to the bridge, Steregushchy!
You certainly are a busy one, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Radiolokatsiya, Kapitan.
Radio location? This just looks like a normal radio to me, Steregushchy.
Da, Kapitan! I did use a standard issue radio as part of my design, but I modified it to transmit as well as receive. Now it should act like a radio location device to detect approaching Rusalki.
Ah, I see! So those wires run over to that big antenna you've mounted over there...

Da, Kapitan! The device sends electromagnetic waves into the air. If there are enemy bombers or ships approaching, the waves bounce off and return back to the device. Comrade Steregushchy is a genius!
Midshipman Antonova is a little too kind in her praise of me, but her technical summary is correct. If the waves return to the device, then we know enemies are approaching.

Fields.MenuText: This could eliminate surprise attacks and give us a lot more warning time to get ready!
It sounds revolutionary - if you can get it to work.
It still sounds like magic to me. I'll believe it when I see it.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, electromagnetic waves are invisible, Kapitan. However, you should be able to see the device working if it detects an enemy.
All of the theories I have read about in my scientific journals indicate the device should work, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan! I am glad you realize the potential! The application of scientific theory to a device that can save lives is truly exciting!
With an operational radio location device, the Rusalki can no longer ambush us, Kapitan. The ship and crew will be much safer.
Oh, Comrade Steregushchy! I admire your tireless devotion to protecting others!
I must make up for my past failures, Midshipman Antonova. My inadequate surveillance almost cost us your life.
Do not worry, Comrade Steregushchy! With the Kapitan on our side, the Rusalki do not stand a chance!
The Kapitan? Why yes, the Kapitan is quite admirable too...
*BOOM*
Morganas attacking! We need to get this radio location device up and running fast!
@BATTLE
Wow, it certainly is hot down here in the engine room, Midshipman Antonova!
Da, Kapitan! Oof, I am sweating so much already!
*CREEEAK*
Kapitan! I was just on the bridge trying to find you, but the crew said you were down here in the engine room...
Steregushchy! What a surprise! I wasn't expecting you to come down here...
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! You have not been in the engine room since we made glass for the binokl together!
Why do you both seem so surprised? I could also say I was not expecting to find you two down here together, but that would not be entirely true.
We're just down here to inspect the boilers, Steregushchy. I'm not sure what else you're implying.
Inspect the boilers? Midshipman Antonova is the officer in charge of the mess. What business does she have in the engine room?
The heat from the boilers is what powers everything in the kitchen, Comrade Steregushchy. Today there is some kind of problem, though, and our stoves are not working. I asked the Kapitan for help.
Broken stoves may seem like a small matter compared to your many surveillance deficiencies, but the sailors still need to eat to keep the ship running.
My "many surveillance deficiencies?" Midshipman Antonova!
You have said it yourself, Comrade Steregushchy. I am only repeating what you have already admitted...

Fields.MenuText: Steregushchy is a little sensitive about these things, Midshipman Antonova...
We'd all like to improve things around the ship. No need to point any fingers!
Steregushchy isn't perfect, but she's doing her best.

Fields.DialogueText: The junior officers on this ship could really learn to improve their manners, Kapitan!
Perhaps if junior officers were not running around so carelessly in battle, we would not have so many close calls, Kapitan.
Hmph! I certainly know enough to fix a simple kitchen stove by myself, Kapitan!
No need to get irritated, Steregushchy. I'm sure Midshipman Antonova wasn't intending to be rude.
Of course I did not mean to be rude! My apologies, Comrade Steregushchy!
So what did you want to see me about, Steregushchy?
Oh... I... I came to let you know that I am having technical problems with the experimental radio location device. I cannot seem to get it working - at least not yet...
If Comrade Steregushchy does not have a deficiency, then she has a technical problem, Kapitan. The end results are quite similar...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
It's always good to get a break while we're in port for a resupply, isn't it?
Da, Kapitan. I have to admit that all my long hours standing watch and researching radio location were leaving me exhausted. A few days at port have been good for me.
You've overworked yourself lately, so I'm glad you've gotten some rest.
Da, Kapitan. I also restocked my coffee supply. It was running low with all the research I have been doing. I am so close to making an operational radio location device!
Just keep at it, Steregushchy. The technology certainly is promising, and I'm sure you'll figure it out eventually.
*FOOTSTEPS*
My mission into town was a success, Kapitan!
Ah, excellent! I can't thank you enough, Midshipman Antonova!
Da, Kapitan! I cannot believe I found the exact type of wine you wanted! It is so difficult to find anything because of the war, so when I saw they had six bottles, I bought all of them for you!
Midshipman Antonova bought wine for you?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, it's normal for junior officers to run small errands like this.
I was busy supervising the refit on the ship, so I asked her to do a favor for me.
Yes, I can't wait to enjoy all this wine with someone special!

Fields.DialogueText: Buying wine does not sound like very official business to me, Kapitan...
You are always busy, Kapitan. It seems like you have your hand in everything these days...
Da, and it does not take Arkady Koshko to figure out who that will be, Kapitan!
Steregushchy, I'm afraid you're really misinterpreting things again!
Da, Comrade Steregushchy - I do not understand why you have been so irritable lately! I was already going to the market to restock our food supplies, so the Kapitan asked for a small favor.
Perhaps... perhaps I was mistaken, Kapitan - but do not forget that I am always watching!
*ALARM*
Rusalki in the harbor, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
It looks like our refit is running ahead of schedule, Kapitan. Should we use the extra time to do a little more to improve the ship?
It's certainly not the worst-
Still fooling around with that radio location device of yours, Steregushchy?
Da, Kapitan. You cannot call it a radio location device, though - it is still a partially disassembled radio that is failing to do anything productive.
That's too bad. Still struggling with your technical problems?
Da, Kapitan. The scientific theory behind radio location is fairly simple, but the engineering required for practical application is a little more complicated.
You're one of the smartest Belles in the fleet, Steregushchy! It sounds like a tough problem, but I know you'll figure it out eventually.
Do you really mean that, Kapitan? I have been feeling a little... inadequate lately.

Fields.MenuText: Inadequate? You built the biggest binoculars in the history of the Red Fleet!
You're still hung up on that bomber hitting Midshipman Antonova, aren't you?
Well, Midshipman Antonova has really been picking up the slack recently...

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan, but even my binokl were not good enough to prevent a Rusalki bomber from hitting the ship!
Da, Kapitan. My specialty is surveillance, and my capabilities in this area are still deficient...
Oy, enough talk about Midshipman Antonova, Kapitan! I can see that she is your favorite now!
Steregushchy... this war is challenging all of us. Even I feel inadequate sometimes, but we all have responsibilities. We can't quit on each other.
I would never quit on you, Kapitan...
That's good to hear! I'm not quitting on you either, Steregushchy! We can win this war together!
What about after the war, Kapitan? Will we still be together?
After the war? Hell, that's too far away to worry about, Steregushchy!
I see...
*GUNFIRE*
Morganas ahead, Steregushchy! We've got to win this war before we have time to think about anything else!
@BATTLE
Wow, this is fantastic wine, is it not, Kapitan?
Yes, I'm surprised you found my favorite variety in that market, Midshipman Antonova! I can't thank you enough!
*KNOCK*
Enter!
*CREEEAK*
Kapitan, I came to update you on--
Steregushchy...
Oh-hoh! I was not expecting to see Midshipman Antonova in here - drinking wine with you no less!

Fields.MenuText: I just opened the first bottle she got for me, so it was only polite to invite her to share a glass.
We're sampling all the provisions we resupplied with at the last port. It's standard procedure.
Yes, we're in the middle of a meeting. What's the interruption?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose she was the one who found the wine at our last port call...
Hmm... Midshipman Antonova is the officer in charge of mess operations, so that does seem reasonable.
What kind of meeting requires drinking wine with a junior officer behind closed doors, Kapitan?
It's our weekly check in on mess operations, Steregushchy. We just thought we'd liven things up a bit with a glass of wine. It's a miracle that Midshipman Antonova found wine this good in the market.
You have to admit, this is still a rather suspicious scene to walk in on, Kapitan.
The Kapitan and I are just having a meeting, Steregushchy. What is so suspicious about that?
You always act so cheerful and innocent, Midshipman Antonova - but I am starting to see through your facade!
Steregushchy, please calm down! You're jumping to conclusions again!
*ALARM*
Morganas! I'm off to the bridge. Meanwhile, could you two please behave yourselves?
@BATTLE
Just move the binokl a little more to the left, Kapitan...
Oh, I think I see it! So that's Cassiopeia?
Da, Kapitan! It is such a beautiful constellation, is it not?
*FOOTSTEPS*
Kapitan, I see that you and Midshipman Antonova are enjoying stargazing through my binokl...
Technically it is "our" binokl, Comrade Steregushchy. Remember how hard we worked to build it together?
Da... that seems like so long ago now, Midshipman Antonova.
The binoculars belong to the ship, Steregushchy. I thought we weren't supposed to be focusing so much on private property these days anyway, right?
I never would have guessed she would be the possessive type, Kapitan - but here we are!

Fields.MenuText: Please don't antagonize Steregushchy, Midshipman Antonova. You're making things worse.
No one owns anything or anyone around here, Midshipman Antonova!
This is a warship and we're serving the Neutrality Fleet, so let's all focus on our mission.

Fields.DialogueText: The mission is always my priority, Kapitan! I am not the one losing focus...
We need everyone on this ship focused on fighting the Rusalki, Kapitan - and that includes the Comrade of the Fleet.
Of course, Kapitan. The purpose of everything and everyone on this ship is to support the war effort against the Rusalki.
I feel like I am losing support from both of you.
How many times do I have to say that I support you and everyone else on this ship, Steregushchy?
Da, Steregushchy! You have been a little irritable lately - please stop taking things so personally! We all need to work together to fight the Rusalki.
Have I really been acting so irritated? I must apologize. Perhaps it is the lack of sleep - and maybe too much coffee...
I see Morganas ahead, Steregushchy. These binoculars of yours are still helping out a lot! Let's get the guns ready!
@BATTLE
So you said you had something to show us, Midshipman Antonova?
This looks very similar to the radio location device I am working on. You even modified the same type of radio and have copied my wiring design...
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! Your design was a stroke of genius, but I did a little more research and determined the flaw in your thinking that is causing technical problems with the radio transmitter.
I see! So you found an error in Steregushchy's original design, and then you fixed it?
Exactly, Kapitan! Radio location technology is too promising to give up on!
No one has "given up" on radio location technology, Midshipman Antonova! Certainly not me, at least!
Well, your progress has slowed considerably over the last few days, Comrade Steregushchy - I just wanted to help!
I think I have it working now. Let me demonstrate by turning on the machine...
*CLANK*
*STATIC*
*HUM*
It does not seem particularly impressive to me, Kapitan...
*DING*
The radio location device is detecting something approaching, Kapitan! It could be the Rusalki!

Fields.MenuText: You did it! You built a working radio location device, Midshipman Antonova!
Hmm... does the noise mean we should see enemies soon?
I still don't see how this metal box is any better than an alert sailor with a good pair of binoculars.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan - I suppose I did!
Da, Kapitan. It is good news if the device is working properly, although we should be prepared for an engagement immediately!
Trust me, Kapitan - this device is like having a hundred sailors on watch who never get tired - and can also see in the dark!
We will not be sure it works unless we encounter the enemy, Midshipman Antonova...
*BOOM*
The Morganas are right on time! Seems like Midshipman Antonova's radio location device is working exactly as she designed!
It was not her design alone, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
*HUM*
*DING*
Midshipman Antonova's radio location device is detecting enemies approaching! Let's get the crew and guns ready, Steregushchy!
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Your radio location device has completely changed how we fight, Midshipman Antonova! It's so much harder for the Morganas to surprise us now.
Da, Kapitan! It will be difficult for Rusalki bombers to slip through our radio location surveillance now.
I am glad my work laid a strong foundation for you to finish the radio location device, Midshipman Antonova.
Oh... da, Comrade Steregushchy! I am glad I could finish the job that you started!
Well, this radio location device still isn't perfect. There is definitely room for improvement.

Fields.MenuText: It only tells us that a plane or ship is coming, but can't distinguish enemies from allies or civilians.
The device doesn't tell us how many enemies are approaching.
We're never sure exactly how far away they are. We only know that they're getting closer or farther from the device.

Fields.DialogueText: We have been getting a lot of false alarms from merchant ships, Kapitan...
A single scout plane is very different from an entire Rusalki armada, but this device cannot tell the difference, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan. A more precise range would be helpful, since the difference between five and fifteen minutes could change an entire battle.
Da... I do admit there are still improvements to be made, Kapitan.
I'm sure if you and Midshipman Antonova put your heads together again, you can come up with an even better version of this radio location device, Steregushchy!
Her design certainly has a lot of flaws to be corrected, Kapitan!
Midshipman Antonova has been busy tinkering with her radio location device for the last few days. Have you helped her out at all, Steregushchy?
Nyet, Kapitan. Midshipman Antonova is a mess hall officer, so it might be difficult to explain more complicated scientific theories to her.
I'm not quite sure about that, Steregushchy - after all, she didn't have much difficulty improving your radio location design.
I had overlooked some basic errors, Kapitan. It was probably due to lack of sleep. When I reviewed her solutions, they were effective, but fairly crude workarounds.

Fields.MenuText: I won't think any less of you if you admit that Midshipman Antonova knows what she's doing.
At least you realize now how important it is to get a proper amount of sleep.
She knew enough to fix things you couldn't, Steregushchy!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm still not convinced, Kapitan.
Da, Kapitan! When a glorified cook starts catching my mistakes, it is obvious that I have not had enough rest!
The errors were simple, and caused by my exhausted state, Kapitan. I am ashamed to admit that even an amateur could have seen my mistakes.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Zdravstvuyte. I have been looking for you, Kapitan!
Steregushchy and I were just talking about how fortunate we were that you got the prototype radio location device up and working, Midshipman Antonova!
Is that really what we were talking about?
Spasiba, Kapitan and Comrade Steregushchy! I came to tell you that I have improved on some of the radio location deficiencies you pointed out, Kapitan!
That's great!
Da, Kapitan! I have improved the electronics and engineering, so now the device can tell us exactly how many enemies are approaching.
Midshipman Antonova sure acts fast, doesn't she, Steregushchy?
Da, Kapitan - it seems like she moves quickly in all areas of her life...
*GUNFIRE*
Rusalki ahead, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Midshipman Antonova wanted to demonstrate her latest improvement with the radio location device, Steregushchy.
Da, Kapitan. She does like to show off whenever possible...
*FOOTSTEPS*
Kapitan! Comrade Steregushchy! Thank you for coming to see my improved radio location device!
I can't wait to see what you came up with, Midshipman Antonova!
No need to get too excited until we see how the device performs, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Any improvement that benefits the whole ship and crew is exciting to me!
True... but I trust that whatever Midshipman Antonova works on will succeed.

Fields.DialogueText: You used to say such things about me, Kapitan...
Midshipman Antonova sure does know how to get you excited, Kapitan...

Fields.MenuText: You're right - Midshipman Antonova is working with very experimental technology.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, and on top of that, she is a cook playing at being a scientist, Kapitan!
Comrade Steregushchy seems a little skeptical, but I assure you that I have improved the precision of the device to accurately identify the number of enemies approaching.
Well, let's see it in action then.
Da, Kapitan!
*CLANK*
*STATIC*
*HUM*
*DING*
The device has detected enemy ships approaching, Kapitan!
Sound the alarm! How many are there?
Between one and seven, Kapitan!
Between one and seven? That's a huge range, Midshipman Antonova!
This is what you get when you rely on a cook to do your engineering, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Midshipman Antonova's radio location device is helpful, but there's still a lot of room for improvement.
To be honest, she is pushing the limits of modern technology. The binokl I built are still the biggest in the history of the Red Fleet, and they continue to give us an advantage against the Rusalki.
That's true, Steregushchy. Those big binoculars of yours can still see further and more clearly than the observation equipment on most other ships.
I know the radio location device is still not perfect, Kapitan, but there is so much potential! I will continue to do my best to improve it!
The radio location device is a useful novelty, Midshipman Antonova, but it does not replace the need for optical observation. It is certainly less accurate and less precise than my binokl.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, we still rely on optical rangefinding for targeting the weapons.
Radio technology is improving quickly. It will replace optical surveillance soon enough.
Both radio location and optical surveillance are useful for the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! We must be able to see the enemy clearly to put accurate fire on it.
Perhaps, Kapitan - but we can only fight the Rusalki with the equipment we actually have, not with the equipment we can only dream about!
We can do everything we need with optical surveillance, Kapitan. Let us not get too distracted by radio location.
You were the first one to say we needed radio location capabilities, Comrade Steregushchy! Remember when a bomber hit our ship because of the limitations of your binokl?
Da, Midshipman Antonova. We have explored radio location enough though, and it also has its limits. We should focus on improving our operating procedures with optical surveillance instead.
Comrade Steregushchy, the only reason you want to abandon radio location is because I made it work after you had failed!
How dare you speak to me that way, Midshipman Antonova?! You are just a simple cook who caught the eye of the Kapitan!
Now wait a minute, both of you! You're both being extremely out of line here!
But what I said is true, is it not, Kapitan? I have succeeded where Steregushchy has failed!
Ha! What I said is true, do you not agree, Kapitan? She is just a simple cook who knows how to charm lonely senior officers!
*BOOM*
Those Morganas got the jump on us again! We need to focus on fighting the enemy, not each other!
@BATTLE
A little time in port will help you and Midshipman Antonova cool off a bit. I don't know what's gotten into you, but you both need to start working together again.
She has been quite rude to me lately, Kapitan.
You're not helping things either. Both of you used to work so well together. What changed?
Midshipman Antonova is obviously very jealous of the close relationship we have, and is trying to come between us, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: We all have a close relationship. We're a crew that needs to work together.
I think you've misinterpreted a lot of things you've seen with Midshipman Antonova and me.
I have a strictly professional relationship with everyone on board, including you.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan, which is why I become so irritated with Midshipman Antonova's desire to cause trouble!
Science is about observation, hypothesis, and testing, Kapitan. I am confident I am not making misinterpretations.
You have said differently in the past, Kapitan, but I suppose a more interesting star has caught your eye...
We need to focus on winning this war before anything else, Steregushchy - and that means everyone on the ship has to work together professionally.
Da, Kapitan. I cannot argue with that.
*GUNFIRE*
Rusalki are approaching the shore, Kapitan! Let us go out there and sink them before they cause any more trouble!
@BATTLE
The limits of radio location are obvious, Kapitan.
As are the limits of Steregushchy and her big binokl, Kapitan! Remember that bomber she let slip through? The explosion almost killed me.
You two aren't getting along any better now, are you? Whatever you two are fighting about - can't you just let it go?
If Midshipman Antonova thinks radio location is so much better than traditional optical surveillance, it would be great if she could actually prove it!
Ha! Is that a challenge, Comrade Steregushchy? My radio location device can easily outperform your obsolete pair of binokl!
Go ahead and show us, Midshipman Antonova! Your last big improvement hardly impressed the Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: The last thing we need is you two fighting!
Like I said, all of the equipment on this ship is useful in keeping us safe!
If we prove one is better than the other, I can finally get some peace and quiet around here.

Fields.DialogueText: The only way to get Midshipman Antonova back in line is to show her how wrong she is, Kapitan.
If everything is useful, Midshipman Antonova needs to learn to stop badmouthing others, Kapitan!
There is no question which one of us would come out on top, Kapitan!
How good are your binokl at detecting the enemy now that the sun is going down, Steregushchy?
The night affects us and the Rusalki equally, Midshipman Antonova.
You did not answer my question, Comrade Steregushchy! Can your binokl see in the dark?
What kind of ridiculous question is that? How can anyone see in the dark?
*DING*
My radio location device has detected Rusalki approaching, Kapitan! We should alert the crew.
Good work, Midshipman Antonova! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
It's raining cats and dogs out there!
Da, Kapitan. Visibility is bad, so we should be careful around the shoreline over there.
We had intel about Morgana activity in the area. I'd hate to run into them in weather like this, but I suppose they'd be just as surprised as us.
We just need to be ready for anything, Kapitan.
*FOOTSTEPS*
The weather is terrible, Kapitan, but it should not have too much of an effect on the performance of my radio location device. Do not worry, Kapitan - I am on watch!

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad the radio location device is still working, even if we can't see anything out there.
It won't help with targeting, but will at least give us some warning if enemies are close.
We're so lucky to have you on our crew, Midshipman Antonova!

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! It does not matter how big your binokl is in a situation like this!
Da, Kapitan. Of course if the Rusalki get close enough for us to see in this weather, hitting them should be easy!
We're also lucky to have a kapitan as good as you, Kapitan!
We will still need sailors on watch to locate the Rusalki, Kapitan. The radio location device lacks rangefinding capability, so optical rangefinding is still the only way to hit a target.
That's true, Steregushchy! We're expecting contact in the area, so please get back to your observatory pod and keep watch with the other sailors. We'll need your help soon!
Da, Kapitan! You can always count on me!
*FOOTSTEPS*
I am still not good enough to win you over from her! What does she have that I do not, Kapitan?!
What on earth are you talking about, Midshipman Antonova? Both of you have been acting so strange lately!
*DING*
Rusalki approaching, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
There's so much mist out there! We better be on guard for Morganas.
Da, Kapitan. The mist has lowered visibility, but we can still detect anything approaching within a few hundred meters.
That'll have to be good enough. Keep your eyes open, Steregushchy.
Da, Kapitan!
At least we have the radio location device to help out, right Midshipman Antonova?
*STATIC*
Oy... actually, the radio location device is not working at the moment, Kapitan. There is something about the mist and the Rusalki interfering with the electromagnetic waves...

Fields.MenuText: That's unfortunate. That device is such an advantage when it's working properly.
New technology always has problems, but I'm sure you and Steregushchy can improve the design.
We'll just have to rely on Steregushchy and the other sailors on watch.

Fields.DialogueText: Da - I am not sure what is happening! This is the first time I have ever experienced a performance problem, Kapitan!
Hmph. I suppose I will be alone in figuring out a solution, Kapitan!
I will try to get the radio location device operational again as soon as possible, Kapitan!
It seems like you are experiencing a bit of equipment failure, Midshipman Antonova.
It is not my fault, Comrade Steregushchy! It is the mist!
Da, let us blame the problem on the mist!
Well, I am off to my observatoriya to man my binokl, Kapitan!
Thanks, Steregushchy! That's exactly where we need you. We'd be sailing around blind without your help. Let us know if you see anything!
Da, Kapitan! Of course!
@BATTLE
This mist just isn't going anywhere, is it?
There is nothing we can do about it, Kapitan. We must stay alert.
How long have you been on watch now?
... About 12 hours, Kapitan. I have had enough coffee, so do not worry.
You still look sharp, so I trust you'll spot any Morganas as soon as they come through the mist.
Da, it is the best we can do without the radio location device working properly.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think you can help Midshipman Antonova get the device running again?
We're doing just fine with you on watch, Steregushchy.
That radio location device is so helpful when it's working...

Fields.DialogueText: The electromagnetic intereference from the mist is something that will be very difficult to counteract, Kapitan. I admit that Midshipman Antonova is not really to blame here.
Da, Kapitan. Radio location is still very promising, but we can always rely on the traditional approach.
Da, Kapitan. The technology has so much potential, which is why I started studying it in the first place.
I think we could improve our radio location device a lot if both you and Midshipman Antonova worked on it together - like you did with the gigantic binoculars you built.
Perhaps, Kapitan...
I don't even know why you two started feuding, but it's not getting us anywhere.
Da, Kapitan - neither of us seem to be getting anywhere with you anyway!
What to do you mean by that? Where are you trying to go with me?
Oh-hoh - sometimes I wonder how someone as dense as you can float on the ocean, Kapitan!
*GUNFIRE*
The sailors must have spotted Rusalki, Kapitan. Boyevyye stantsii!
@BATTLE
I hope you had a few nights of good rest while we've been in port, Steregushchy.
I slept well enough, Kapitan, but I had a few late nights chatting with Midshipman Antonova.
Really? Huh - that's a surprise! You two had really been getting on each other's nerves lately!
Da, Kapitan. We realized we were competing for something that neither of us could win. We started talking about radio location theories instead, and decided that was more interesting than fighting.
You were competing over something? I've just been too busy focusing on beating the Morganas to pay attention to anything else.
That has become very obvious, Kapitan.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Comrade Steregushchy! I found some scientific journals on radio location in the local library!
Spasiba, Midshipman Antonova! I look forward to another late night researching with you in your cabin.
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! We have so much to discover together! I also picked up two bottles of wine in the market - I'm sure that will help!
Huh... great that you two are getting along again! Did you pick up any wine for me this time, Midshipman Antonova?
Oy! I completely forgot to pick up wine for you, Kapitan! My apologies!
It seems that her memory is not so good these days, Kapitan. Perhaps there is another junior officer who can run errands for you?
*BOOM*
No more time for wine, Steregushchy! We've got some Morganas to take care of!
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Did you see that flash of light?!
Da, Kapitan! I do not think it was the Rusalki this time - I think we were just struck by lightning!
Oy! The lightning knocked out all of our electronics, including the radio location device!
The bridge is useless without power! Call some engineers in here to get everything back up and running!
Da, Kapitan!
Steregushchy, we need your eyes on watch! I will try to get the radio location device operational as soon as possible!
Da, Midshipman Antonova! I will head down to the deck. I know I can trust you to take care of things on the bridge.

Fields.MenuText: This attitude change between you and Antonova is like night and day!
We've got to work together to keep the ship safe until we get our electronics back up!
You're suddenly trusting Midshipman Antonova to fix the ship's electronics?

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! My comments about her being a dumb cook were just to get under her skin - but that is all in the past. She has quite a good understanding of physics and engineering!
Da, Kapitan. We realized we share many of the same interests, and it is better to work together than to argue - especially when we have a war to win!
Da, Kapitan! I will stand watch for the Rusalki while Midshipman Antonova restores power on the bridge! Do not worry!
Fighting the Morganas is a hell lot easier now that you two aren't at each other's throats!
Da, Kapitan! I am off to my observatoriya! Good luck in here!
We do not need luck when we have you on our side, Steregushchy!
@BATTLE
We have engineers working on the bridge, but Midshipman Antonova says it'll be a while before all our electrical systems are back up and running.
I am sure she will get the job done as quickly as possible, Kapitan. It was bad luck for the ship to get struck by lightning, but even worse to run into Rusalki immediately afterwards.
You spotted all their ships quickly, though, and the gunner's mates sank them soon enough!
Da, Kapitan. This is what all of us are trained to do.

Fields.MenuText: Things are running so smoothly now that you and Midshipman Antonova are back on good terms!
A ship is only as good as its crew!
Our surveillance capabilities would be so much worse without you, Steregushchy!

Fields.DialogueText: We share similar goals, Kapitan - neither of us will give up until we win this war!
Da, and we are lucky to have excellent officers like you and Midshipman Antonova!
Spasiba, Kapitan. I am just doing my part.
I have to admit that Midshipman Antonova was the one responsible for making the radio location device operational. She had very clever solutions for my errors!
So do you think both of you can continue to improve the design?
Da, Kapitan. To be honest, radio location technology has the potential to make optical surveillance completely obsolete.
That sounds like science fiction to me! It's hard to believe anything could replace a sailor on watch with a sharp pair of eyes.
Our understanding of the world continues to improve, Kapitan. Technological advancements are already changing how we fight wars.
War is a terrible thing, Steregushchy. It's tough to say we're making advancements when we're just getting better at destroying each other.
Da, Kapitan... although technology can help save lives, too. I hope that is what we can achieve with radio location.
*BOOM*
We'll never find peace with these Morganas around, though, so let's get back to work!
@BATTLE
We have power back on the bridge, Kapitan! The radios are functioning, and the radio location device is operational too!
That's good to hear. There's a heavy Morgana presence in the area, so we're bound to run into more of them before too long.
I should get back to my observatoriya as soon as possible.
Da, Comrade Steregushchy, but before you go, I have another improvement to the radio location device I would like to show you!
That is great news, Midshipman Antonova! Did you finally figure out how to operationalize the pulsed wave design we discussed to measure enemy distance and velocity?
Da, Comrade Steregushchy! Our long nights of research together in my cabin have been very productive! The wine we shared gave me courage to explore entirely new directions!

Fields.MenuText: Amazing things happen when you put two great minds together!
Your research methods seem a little unorthodox, but I can't argue with the results!
These research parties sound fun. Why am I not invited?

Fields.DialogueText: I do not mean to be rude, Kapitan, but you lack the proper level of understanding in physics and electrical engineering to contribute anything useful.
Da, Kapitan! We both share a passion for science!
Achieving what we wanted required a non-traditional approach, Kapitan. We were both quite satisfied with the design we reached at the end.
*DING*
The new pulsed wave system is working, Kapitan!
Fantastic job - both of you!
Spasiba, Kapitan!
Da, spasiba, Kapitan!
We have several Rusalki approaching, and they're closing in fast!
We need you back on deck to spot those incoming Morganas, Steregushchy!
Da, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
That pulsed wave improvement you and Midshipman Anotonova made to the radio location device is fantastic!
Da, Kapitan! Not only do we get early warning of approaching Rusalki, but we have a better idea of their numbers, speed and distance.
The Rusalki in this area are some of the toughest we have seen in a while, Kapitan! We need any advantage we can get!
I'll need both of you staying on top of things if we want to fight our way through these Morganas without taking any losses.
Steregushchy is always on top of things, Kapitan! We will not let you down!
*DING*
The radio location device is detecting something, Midshipman Antonova!
Another wave of Rusalki closing in quickly, Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: There can't be many more of them! Let's finish them off!
They don't stand a chance against a crew like ours!
I'm not sure how long we can hold out if these Morganas keep coming...

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan! I will relay their positions as soon as I spot them!
Da, Kapitan - the combination of radio location and superior optical surveillance will make it difficult for any bombers to sneak through this time!
I am confident we can sink them all if we work together, Kapitan!
The radio location device indicates this is not even the last wave of Rusalki, Steregushchy! There are so many of them this time!
Your warning has already given us an advantage, Midshipman Antonova. I need to get back to my observatoriya, but I trust you and the Kapitan can handle things alone on the bridge.
You really do not mind leaving me alone with the Kapitan, Steregushchy?
Ha! We both gave up on the Kapitan a long time ago, Midshipman Antonova. I am quite happy we both decided to pursue other interests!
Da, Steregushchy! I could not agree with you more!
What do you mean you both gave up on me? All you two talk about these days is how we'll never give up, and we all fight better as a team!
Da, Kapitan - please keep your focus on the battle. That is what you are good at...
@BATTLE
The radio location device is indicating one last group of Morganas, Steregushchy! From the looks of things, it's not going to be an easy fight!
We will do our best as always, Kapitan!
*GUNFIRE*
@BATTLE
We sank every Rusalki in range, Kapitan!
Da, it is only clear blue skies and calm water through my binokl, Kapitan!
That was a hell of a long engagement, and the Morganas didn't stop coming! We couldn't have made it out of there without help from both of you. I think this calls for a little celebration...

Fields.MenuText: Why don't I jump in that observatory pod of yours for some private stargazing, Steregushchy?
Why don't you grab a bottle of wine and meet me in my cabin, Midshipman Antonova?
Why don't all three of us have an after-hours party together in the mess?

Fields.DialogueText: That hardly sounds like a celebration, Kapitan. My observatoriya does not have room for more than one, considering all the books and equipment I have in there.
I am afraid Steregushchy and I have finished all the wine during our late night research meetings, Kapitan. We will have to resupply at the next port.
We would hate to keep you up after all this fighting, Kapitan. You need to get your rest too.
We really do not have the energy to celebrate after all that action, Kapitan...
Well, the radio location device isn't indicating any more enemies in the area. I suppose we can all take some time to relax.
Da, Kapitan - rest does sound good!
Shall we head back to your cabin, Midshipman Antonova?
Oh, I was waiting for you to ask, Comrade Steregushchy! Remember that new science journal on electromagnetism I picked up at the last port? Maybe we can read it together?
Ah, what a fantastic idea! That sounds perfect!
Well... you two seem to have your plans for the evening, but it still sounds like work to me! I suppose I'll just retire back to my cabin and get some sleep...
Dobroy nochi, Kapitan!
Have pleasant dreams, Kapitan! We will see you again in the morning!
